key_insight: Standardized psychometric tests can reliably measure personality-like traits in instruction-tuned LLMs, and those trait profiles can be validated and deliberately reproduced to influence downstream behavior.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of rigorous, validated methods for measuring and shaping personality-like behavior in large language models, which previously limited evaluation, controllability, and comparability.
method: Adapt established psychometric instruments (e.g., Big Five-style items) into model prompts and score model responses as trait measures.
Establish reliability and validity via statistical tests (internal consistency, test–retest, convergent/discriminant validation) across model families and settings.
Shape or mimic target personality profiles using conditioning or prompt/fine-tuning interventions and evaluate effects on downstream tasks.
impact: Gives AI/ML practitioners reproducible tools to audit, personalize, and steer LLM behavior along interpretable personality dimensions, improving safety, user alignment, and benchmark design.
visual_elements: Pipeline flowchart: prompt design → response scoring → psychometric validation → profile shaping
Bar/line chart comparing reliability (e.g., Cronbach’s alpha, test–retest) across model sizes and instruction tuning
Radar/spider plots showing human vs. model personality profiles and altered profiles after interventions
Before/after examples: sample prompts and downstream outputs illustrating controlled personality shifts
paper_title: A psychometric framework for evaluating and shaping personality traits in large language models
paper_authors: Gregory Serapio-García, Mustafa Safdari, Clément Crepy, Luning Sun, Stephen Fitz
